form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service, A2 875947

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 U.S. tment of Justice Immigration and Naturalization Service John Fitzgerald Kennedy Federal Building Government Center Boston, Massachusetts 02203 PLEASE REFER TO THIS FILE NUMBER Mrs. Rosegarcon Idora Petit A26 875947 48 Fuller Street, 3rd/fl. Dorchester, MA. 02124 APR 15 1986 Dear Mrs. Petit: On December 3, 1985 you filed this Motion to Reconsider your application for adjustment of status to permanent resident (Form I-485) which was denied on November 8, 1985. Within your submission you sent Form I-601 "Application for Waiver of Grounds of Excludability" on account of visa fraud pursuant to Section 212 (a) (19) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Your waiver application will be rejected and processed for a refund as you are not "otherwise admissible" as required by Section 212 (i) of the Act. Your application for permanent resident on reconsideration is, however, denied again under Section 212 (a) (15) of the Act due to the likelihood of becoming a public charge in the United States. Your original application for permanent residence was denied pursuant to Section 212 (a) (15) and (19). In your instant Motion you have sought to address the issue of public charge by submitting a new affidavit of support (Form I-134) from your daughter showing her annual income to be $9,776.00 in addition to the income previously shown on your son-in-law's Form I-134 of $14,200. The total available income of only approximately $24,000. must support in addition to yourself the affiants' three minor children. In addition you have submitted a letter from the "Prudential Insurance Company" confirming issuance of a supplementary Group Hospital Insurance Plan. In view of your advanced age a comprehensive medical insurance plan is paramount. The plan you have purchased is designed to supplement with small, fixed, daily dollar benefits any underlying basic medical expenses of even a modest hospitalization and provides no benefits at all for non-hospital medical costs. In view of the modest income and large number of dependents of your sponsors, it is unlikely that they could meet your expected medical expenses from their own resources. Moreover, you have not presented evidence of withdrawal of the application you made on 08/07/85 to the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare for Federal Medicaid benefits to cover medical needs. Accordingly, we again conclude pursuant to Section 212 (a) (15) of the Act that you are likely to become a public charge in the United States and, thus are statutorily ineligible for adjustment of status to permanent resident. Sincerely, Charla Cobl Charles T. Cobb District Director

SERVICES BY MORE THAN ONE PHYSICIAN Except as described in the benefit section on page 7. we will not provide benefits for medical services that are furnished by MORE than ONE physician. 19. COORDINATION OF BENEFITS INTRODUCTION We will apply "coordination of benefits" to all the benefits described in your contract. The coordination of benefits program, known as COB. applies to you if YOU or ANY of your dependents have another plan which provides coverage for your hospital. medical, dental or other health care expenses. This program is designed to prevent people from making a profit from health insurance by collecting more than the actual charge for their covered health care services. This practice eventually leads to increased costs of health care for all of us. COB regulates all benefit payments for covered services so that the total payments received from all insurance programs do not exceed the total charge for those covered services. WE will decide which plan should provide benefits first. The plan that provides benefits first is known as the primary plan. The primary plan is responsible for providing benefits to the full extent of their coverage. The plan that provides benefits next is known as the secondary plan. The secondary plan provides benefits towards any remaining balance of covered services as long as the payment. when added to the primary plan's payment. is not more than the total amount of the covered benefit expenses. HOW TO DETERMINE THE PRIMARY PLAN We will decide who is the primary and secondary plan by the same rules that are used throughout the insurance industry. Those rules are: A. If only one of the plans has COB, the plan that DOES NOT is the primary plan. B. When both plans have COB the rules listed below will apply: 1. If the patient is the subscriber under one plan and a covered dependent under another, the plan through which he or she is the subscriber is the primary plan. ge 18 2. If the patient is a covered dependent under the plan of both a male and a female subscriber, the male's plan is the primary plan.

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Mrs. Rosegarcon Idora Petit A26 875947 48 Fuller Street, 3rd/fl. Dorchester, MA. 02124 APR 15 1986 Dear Mrs. Petit: On December 3, 1985 you filed this Motion to Reconsider your application for adjustment of status to permanent resident (Form I-485) which was denied on November 8, 1985. within your submission you sent Form I-601 "Application for Waiver of Grounds of Excludability" on account of visa fraud pursuant to Section 212 (a) (19) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Your waiver application will be rejected and processed for a refund as you are not "otherwise admissible" as required by Section 212 (i) of the Act. Your application for permanent resident on reconsideration is, however, denied again under Section 212 (a) (15) of the Act due to the likelihood of becoming a public charge in the United States. Your original application for permanent residence was denied pursuant to Section 212( (a) (15) and (19). In your instant Motion you have sought to address the issue of public charge by submitting a new affidavit of support (Form I-134) from your daughter showing her annual income to be $9,776.00 in addition to the income previously shown on your son-in-law's Form I-134 of $14,200. The total available income of only approximately $24,000. must support in addition to yourself the affiants' three minor children. In addition you have submitted a letter from the "Prudential Insurance Company" confirming issuance of a supplementary Group Hospital Insurance Plan. In view of your advanced age a comprehensive medical insurance plan is paramount. The plan you have purchased is designed to supplement with small, fixed, daily dollar benefits any underlying basic medical expenses of even a modest hospitalization and provides no benefits at all for non-hospital medical costs. In view of the modest income and large number of dependents of your sponsors, it is unlikely that they could meet your expected medical expenses from their own resources. Moreover, you have not presented evidence of withdrawal of the application you made on 08/07/85 to the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare for Federal Medicaid benefits to cover medical needs. Accordingly, we again conclude pursuant to Section 212(a)(15) of the Act that you are likely to become a public charge in the United States and, thus are statutorily ineligible for adjustment of status to permanent resident. Sincerely, Charls T. Cobb Charles T. Cobb District Director

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: DECISION

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 DECISION On May 1, 1985 you applied for adjustment of status to permanent residence (Form I-485) based on the visa petition of your United States Citizen daughter Mrs. Marie Magny approved on April 1, 1985 under Section 201(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. on July 24, 1935 accompanied and assisted by your son-in-law, you were interviewed under oath by an Innigration Examiner as to your eligibility for adjustment of status. Your application will be denied pursaunt to Section 212 (a) (15) and (19), respectively referring to excludability due to the likelihood of becoming a public charge and for visa fraud. The record indicates that you are nearly 80 years of age, having been born in Haiti on December 1, 1905 and that you are not now, nor for the last five years have you been employed. To demonstrate financial support you submitted an Affidavit of Support (Form I-134) signed May 17, 1985 by your son-in-lew stating that he would support you based on his annual income of $13,500, his savings of 91990 and stocks and bonds worth $7, 776. In addition #your daughterythe petitioner, submitted FL job letter stating she was employed full-time in a clerical position, but no salary data was offered. Your daughter and son-in-law also reveal that they must support three minor children of their own. Since you are living with your daughter, the principal financial issue is security against medical expenses. You were asked at the interview to submit proof of comprehensive medical insurance to cover you in the United States. In reply you sent a Medicaid Verification Checklist" dated August 7, 1985 from the Department of Public Welfare, 43 Hawkins Street, Boston, MA 02114 apparently constituting an application on your part for medicaid assistance from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Section 212(a)(15) of the Act provides for the exclusion of aliens from the United States " who, in the opinion of the consular officer at the time of application for a visa, or in the opinion of the Attorney General at the time of application for admission, are likely at any time to become public charges". Matter of Harutunian, 14 I&N Dec. 503, a precedent decision binding upon the Immigration Service concludes that: any alien who is incapable of earning U livelihood who does not have sufficient funds in the United States for his support, and has no person in the United States willing and able to assure that he will not need public support is excludable as likely to become a public charge whether or not the public support which will be available to him is reimbursable to the state. In all analysis right on point the decision goes on to state: "Everything in the statutes, the legislative comments and the decisions points to one conclusion, that Congress intends that an applicant for a visa be excluded who is without sufficient funds to support himself, who has no one under any obligation to support him and who, being older, has an increasing chance of become dependent, disabled and sick".

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 - 2 - Based on the foregoing, we conclude that you are an alien likely to become a public charge. In view of your age and lack of private medical insurance there is a very high probability that you will incur expensive pedical bills within the foreseable future that your sponsors simply could not afford to puy-out-of-yocket in view of their income and primary support obligations to their three children. While the District Director may, as a matter of discretion, allow your sponsors to post a Public Charge Bond in your behalf pursuant to Section 213 of the Act, such a bond to assure you would not become e public charge would be pointless since we are not questioning the good intentions of your sponsors but their inability to pay exborbitant but expected medical bills without insurance. The fact that you have apparently already applied for Medicaid, a publicly funded program to pay for the medical care of the indigent, underscores our analysis. The record further indicates that you entered the United States on December 30, 1984 as a "B-2" visitor based on a visa issued by the American Embassy in Port-au-Prince on December 13, 1984. At your sworn interview you insisted that you told the American Consul that you were coming only to "visit" the United States for a period of "one year". You denied that you had a preconceived intention which you concealed from the Consul to innigrate to the United States despite the fact that you came only with a one-way airline ticket and your actual application for permanent residence was filed only one month after your arrival here. You were completely unable to articulate any objective explanation of why you have chosen to remain in the United States with your daughter. A copy of yor nonimmigrant visa application has been obtained from the American Embassy and reveals that you did not request a stay of one year in the United States but only "8 days" (item #29) to come to "Boston" for "tourism" Section (212) (a) (19) of the Act provides for the exclusion of: 11 "...Any alien who seeks to procure, or has sought to procure, or has procured a visa or other docurentation, or seeks to enter the United States, by fraud, or by willfully rd rropresenting EL material fact". The definition exposition in case law precedents binding upon the Immigration Service concerning Section 212(a)(19) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is found in Matter of S & B-C 9 I & if Dec. 430. The case defines the materiality of a wisrepresentation. It is material if "(A) the alien is excludable on the true facts, or (3) the misrepresentation tends to shut off u line of inquiry which is relevant to the alien's eligibility and which might well have resulted in a proper determination that he be excluded". Had your true intention of seeking to remain indefinitely in the United States been known to the Consular Officer you would have been ineligible to receive a visitor's visa (Section 214(b) and Section 101(a)(15)(B) because you lacked a forei residence which you had no intention of abandoning and did not immediately qualify for an invigrant visa. By failing to admit what we now hold to be the true facts surrounding your waiver visitor's visa, you have also failed to avail yourself OI' the possibility of (Form I-601) pursuant to Section 212(1) of the Act. Accordingly you are statutorily ineligible for admission into the United States or for an immigrant visa due to your violation of Section 212(a)(19) of the Act.

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: YOUR DEPENDENT LIFE INSURANCE PLAN, 59-7130

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 YOUR DEPENDENT LIFE INSURANCE PLAN Your Dependent Life Insurance Plan is insured with The Travelers Insurance Company. This Plan offers you life insur- ance protection for your dependents at low group rates. In the event of a dependent's death, the amount of his or her coverage will be paid to you. Eligibility If you are a permanent employee, you may enroll your dependents in the Dependent Life Insurance Plan on your first day of active work. Dependents eligible for coverage are: Your spouse Your unmarried children between the ages of 14 days and 19 years Your unmarried children from age 19 to their 23rd birthday, who have their legal residence with you, are wholly depen- dent upon you for maintenance and support, and who are registered full-time students Dependent children 19 years of age or older who are physi- cally or mentally handicapped, if they are covered as depen- dents up until their 19th birthday. You must provide proof of their inability to engage in self-sustaining employment within 31 days of their 19th birthday PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7130, AUGUST, 1983 1

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Screeneded by NARA, 8/11/2023, PUBLICATION NUMBER SR-7130, AUGUST, 1983

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Children who may be covered include stepchildren, legally adopted children, foster children, and other children who are financially dependent upon you and live with you in a regular parent-child relationship. If you enroll your family within one month of your first day of active work, or if you enroll your spouse within one month of your marriage, no medical examination is required. If you enroll your dependents after these dates, proof of their good health may be required. Effective Dates If you enroll your dependents within one month of your first day of active work, or if you enroll your spouse within one month of your marriage, their coverage will become effective on your first day of active work or the date of your marriage, providing you have authorized payroll deductions to begin. If you enroll your dependents or spouse after these dates, their coverage will be subject to the consent of the insurance company and will become effective on the day the insurance company accepts their proof of good health. Amount of Coverage For your dependents, the amount of coverage is determined by a multiple of your annual base rate of pay, depending on your spouse's age. Your annual base rate of pay is your basic annual salary or wage, including any sales or executive incen- tive pay, but not including overtime, shift premium, bonuses, or other forms of extra income. If your spouse is under 30, he or she will be covered under the highest benefit amount, or 100% of your annual pay. If your spouse is age 65 or older, he or she will be covered under the lowest benefit amount, or 40% of your annual pay. The maximum amount of coverage for your spouse is $100,000. Each eligible dependent child's amount of coverage will be equal to 25% of your annual base rate of pay. The maximum amount of coverage for each eligible dependent child is $25,000. 2 PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7130, AUGUST, 1983

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023, PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7130, AUGUST, 1983

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Use the table below to compute your dependents' coverage. Find your spouse's age group, then match it with the ap- propriate number under "Spouse's Coverage." Multiply that number by your annual base rate of pay. The example shows that for an employee who makes $13,000 and whose spouse is age 25, the amount of coverage is $13,000. Each child's coverage is equal to .25 of the employee's pay, which in this example is equal to $3,250. Age of Spouse's Coverage Child's Coverage Spouse (multiple of employee's pay) Under 30 1.00 x 13,000 = $13,000 .25 X $13,000 = $3,250 30-34 .90 .25 35-39 .80 .25 40-44 .70 .25 45-49 .60 .25 50-64 .50 .25 65 and over .40 .25 Cost Your cost for Dependent Life Insurance is .20% of your monthly base rate of pay up to a maximum of $30 per month. Your monthly base rate in pay is your basic monthly salary or wage, including any sales or executive incentive pay, but not including overtime, shift premium, bonuses, or other forms of extra income. In the example above, the employee's cost for Dependent Life coverage is $2.17 per month. Payment of Benefits In the event of the death of one of your covered dependents, the full amount of his or her coverage will be paid to you in one lump sum. PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7130, AUGUST, 1983 3

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: FILING A CLAIM, 59-7130

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 FILING A CLAIM For help in filing a death claim with the insurance company, you should contact your Employee Relations/Personnel repre- sentative. If a benefit claim is denied, you will receive a written statement of the reasons for the denial. You have a right to have the denial reviewed if you wish. Included in the statement you receive will be the name and address of the person you should call or write if you want the denial reviewed. TERMINATION OF COVERAGE Your dependent's life insurance coverage will end on the earliest of the following: When your Honeywell employment ends due to resignation, discharge, layoff or normal retirement. The last day of the last period for which you have made the required contribution An individual dependent's coverage will end on the earliest of the above dates or when that person ceases to be an eligible dependent. In the event you retire early (between ages 55 and 65), you may continue your dependents' life insurance coverage up until your 65th birthday by paying the required monthly premium. BENEFITS AFTER TERMINATION OF COVERAGE In the event of the death of your covered spouse within 31 days after your group coverage ends, the full amount of his/her coverage will be paid to you. 4 PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7130, AUGUST. 1983 1

You will be charged the regular rates for a person of your spouse's age and occupation. This policy cannot be converted to an individual policy for any of your dependents except your spouse. form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Supplemental Life Insurance Plan, NARA, 8/11/2023

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Effective Dates: Upon enrolling in the Supplemental Life Insurance Plan within one month of your first day of active work, or within one month of becoming married, your coverage will become effective on your first day of active work or the date of your marriage, providing you have authorized payroll deductions to begin. If you enroll late, coverage will become effective on the day the insurance company accepts your proof of good health. Cost Your cost for Supplemental Life Insurance depends upon the type of coverage you choose. If you select High Option coverage, the cost will be .005 (one-half of one percent) of your monthly base rate of pay. Low Option coverage will cost .0025 (one-fourth of one percent) of your monthly base rate of pay. Monthly base rate of pay is your basic monthly salary or wage, including any sales or executive incentive pay, but not including overtime, shift premium, bonuses, or other forms of extra income. LIFE INSURANCE COVERAGE The amount of Supplemental Life Insurance coverage is determined according to the age group you are in and your annual base rate of pay. (To find your coverage, see the table in Amount of Coverage.) The amount of insurance will automatically be adjusted as your pay and age group change. Increases in the amount of insurance will become effective only when you are actively at work. If you continue to work after age 65, your Supplemental Life Insurance will continue in force. (See chart in Amount of Coverage.) If you are a retired employee who is rehired by the company you may reenroll in the Supplemental Life Insurance Plan. The amount of your insurance coverage can also be determined by using the table under Amount of Coverage. 2 PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7123, JUNE, 1985

Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Amount of Coverage Two coverage options are provided: High Option coverage and Low Option coverage. The following Age Group/Option table can be used to compute your coverage by selecting your age group, then multiplying the appropriate "Option" number by your annual base rate of pay. The example in the table illustrates that an employee 40 years old who has an annual base rate of pay equal to $20,000 is entitled to $50,000 at a monthly cost of $8.33 if he or she elects High Option coverage, or $25,000 at a monthly cost of $4.17 if he or she elects Low Option coverage. The coverage amount will change automatically if the employee's pay changes, or when the employee reaches age 45. High Option Age Group (multiple of employee pay) Under 30 4.0 30-34 3.5 35-39 3.0 40-44 2.5 X $20,000=$50,000 coverage 45-49 2.0 50-69 1.5 Low Option Age Group (multiple of employee pay) Under 30 2.00 30-34 1.75 35-39 1.50 40-44 1.25 X $20,000=$25,000 coverage 45-49 1.00 50-69 .75 You may change from High Option coverage to Low Option coverage at any time. No medical examination is required. However, to change from Low Option coverage to High Option coverage you must submit written proof of your good health, acceptable to the insurance company. PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7123, JUNE, 1985 3

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: RETIREE LIFE INSURANCE

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 RETIREE LIFE INSURANCE For Early Retirees Between Ages 55 and 65 Eligibility-Participating in the Supplemental Life Insurance Plan for at least one or more years immediately prior to early retirement makes you eligible to 1) continue the full amount of your employee group Supplemental Life insurance coverage up to age 65; or 2) continue a reduced amount if you elect to participate in the Retiree Life Insurance (See Amount of Coverage-Retirees Age 65 and Over.) Cost-Early retirees between ages 55 and 65 who elect to continue group Supplemental Life Insurance coverage will pay 28c per month for each $1,000 of coverage. If you elect the reduced Retiree Life Insurance, there will be no cost for this coverage. Amount of Coverage-Electing to continue group Supplemen- tal Life Insurance means your coverage will be the same amount as the day before early retirement. If you elect to participate in the Retiree Life Insurance, the amount of your coverage will be reduced. (See Amount of Coverage-Retirees Age 65 and Over.) For Normal and Late Retirees Age 65 and Over Eligibility-Participation in the Supplemental Life Insurance Plan for at least one or more years immediately prior to retirement makes you eligible to have a portion of your coverage continued during retirement as Retiree Life Insurance. Cost-There is no cost to a retiree who participates in the Retiree Life Insurance Plan. 4 PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7123, JUNE, 1985

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Supplemental Life Insurance, PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7123

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Amount of Coverage-Upon retirement you may continue one percent of the Supplemental Life Insurance coverage you had on the day before you retired for each full year (up to a maximum of 30 years) that you were a Plan member. The maximum amount of Retiree Life Insurance coverage provided after age 65 is $25,000. EXAMPLE An employee retires at age 65 after participating in the Sup- plemental Life Insurance Plan for 25 years; coverage amount on the day just before retirement was $30,000. .01 times $30,000 = $300 $300 times 25 years = $7,500 of Retiree Life Insurance coverage after retirement PAYMENT OF BENEFITS In the event of your death, the amount of Supplemental Life Insurance coverage will be paid to your beneficiary. The beneficiary is the person you have named in writing on a form which is on file with the Human Resources department. You may change your selected beneficiary in writing at any time. The forms necessary to change your beneficiary are available from the Human Resources department. Supplemental Life Insurance benefits may be paid to your beneficiary in one of the following ways: A single lump sum Monthly installments with interest The form of payment is selected by the beneficiary. If a beneficiary elects to receive this benefit in monthly install- ments, and dies before receiving the full amount of your coverage, the remainder will be paid to the beneficiary's estate unless you have requested otherwise in your beneficiary desig- nation. PUBLICATION NUMBER 59-7123, JUNE, 1985 5

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: DECISION, I-485

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 DECISION On May 1, 1985 you applied for adjustment of status to permanent residence (Form I-485) based on the visa petition of your United States Citizen daughter Mrs. Marie Magny approved on April 1, 1985 under Section 201(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. On July 24, 1985 accompanied and assisted by your son-in-law, you were interviewed under oath by an Immigration Examiner as to your eligibility for adjustment of status. Your application will be denied pursaunt to Section 212(a)(15) and (19), respectively referring to excludability due to the likelihood of becoming a public charge and for visa fraud. The record indicates that you are nearly 80 years of age, having been born in Haiti on December 1, 1905 and that you are not now, nor for the last five years have you been employed. To demonstrate financial support you submitted an Affidavit of Support (Form I-134) signed May 17, 1985 by your son-in-law stating that he would support you based on his annual income of $13,500, his savings of $1990 and stocks and bonds worth $7,776. In addition #your daughtersthe petitioner, submitted a job letter stating she was employed full-time in a clerical position, but no salary data was offered. Your daughter and son-in-law also reveal that they must support three minor children of their own. Since you are living with your daughter, the principal financial issue is security against medical expenses. You were asked at the interview to submit proof of comprehensive medical insurance to cover you in the United States. In reply you sent a "Medicaid Verification Checklist" dated August 7, 1985 from the Department of Public Welfare, 43 Hawkins Street, Boston, MA 02114 apparently constituting an application on your part for Medicaid assistance from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. Section 212(a) (15) of the Act provides for the exclusion of aliens from the United States " who, in the opinion of the consular officer at the time of application for a visa, or in the opinion of the Attorney General at the time of application for admission, are likely at any time to become public charges". Matter of Harutunian, 14 I&N Dec. 583, a precedent decision binding upon the Immigration Service concludes that: any alien who is incapable of earning a livelihood who does not have sufficient funds in the United States for his support, and has no person in the United States willing and able to assure that he will not need public support is excludable as likely to become a public charge whether or not the public support which will be available to him is reimbursable to the state." " In an analysis right on point the decision goes on to state: "Everything in the statutes, the legislative comments and the decisions points to one conclusion, that Congress intends that an applicant for a visa be excluded who is without sufficient funds to support himself, who has no one under any obligation to support him and who, being older, has an increasing chance of become dependent, disabled and sick".

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 - 2 - Based on the foregoing, we conclude that you are an alien likely to become a public charge. In view of your age and lack of private medical insurance there is a very high probability that you will incur expensive medical bills within the foreseable future that your sponsors simply could not afford to pay-out-of-pocket in view of their income and primary support obligations to their three children. While the District Director may, as a matter of discretion, allow your sponsors to post a Public Charge Bond in your behalf pursuant to Section 213 of the Act, such a bond to assure you would not become a public charge would be pointless since we are not questioning the good intentions of your sponsors but their inability to pay exhorbitant but expected medical bills without insurance. The fact that you have apparently already applied for Medicaid, a publicly funded program to pay for the medical care of the indigent, underscores our analysis. The record further indicates that you entered the United States on December 30, 1984 as a "B-2" visitor based on a visa issued by the American Embassy in Port-au-Prince on December 13, 1984. At your sworn interview you insisted that you told the American Consul that you were coming only to "visit" the United States for a period of "one year". You denied that you had a preconceived intention which you concealed from the Consul to immigrate to the United States despite the fact that you came only with a one-way airline ticket and your actual application for permanent residence was filed only one month after your arrival here. You were completely unable to articulate any objective explanation of why you have chosen to remain in the United States with your daughter. A copy of yor nonimmigrant visa application has been obtained from the American Embassy and reveals that you did not request a stay of one year in the United States but only "8 days" (item #29) to come to "Boston" for "tourism". Section (212) (a) (19) of the Act provides for the exclusion of: If Any alien who seeks to procure, or has sought to procure, or has procured a visa or other documentation, or seeks to enter the United States, by fraud, or by willfully misrepresenting a material fact". The definition exposition in case law precedents binding upon the Immigration Service concerning Section 212(a)(19) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is found in Matter of S & B-C 9 I & N Dec. 436. The case defines the materiality of a misrepresentation. It is material if "(A) the alien is excludable on the true facts, or (B) the misrepresentation tends to shut off a line of inquiry which is relevant to the alien's eligibility and which might well have resulted in a proper determination that he be excluded". Had your true intention of seeking to remain indefinitely in the United States been known to the Consular Officer you would have been ineligible to receive a visitor's visa (Section 214(b) and Section 101(a)(15)(B) because you lacked a foreign residence which you had no intention of abandoning and did not immediately qualify for an immigrant visa. By failing to admit what we now hold to be the true facts surrounding your waiver visitor's visa, you have also failed to avail yourself of the possibility of (Form I-601) pursuant to Section 212(1) of the Act. Accordingly you are statutorily ineligible for admission into the United States or for an immigrant visa due to your violation of Section 212(a)(19) of the Act.

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Screeneded by NARA, 8/11/2023, Attachment to Form I-291 A26 875 947

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 - 3 - Section 245(a) of the Act provides that only an alien who is eligible to receive an immigrant visa and is admissible to the United States for permanent residence may have his/her status adjusted to that of a permanent resident. Since we have held you to be inadmissible (excludable) from the United States pursuant to Sections 212(a)(15), public charge, and (19), visa fraud, you are ineligible for adjustment of status to permanent resident and your application is hereby denied. Attachment to Form I-291 A26 875 947

(If you have never been a member of any organization, state 'None 16. I have not have been treated for a mental disorder, drug addiction or alcoholism. (If you have been, explain.) 17. I have not have been arrested, convicted or confined in a prison. (If you have been, explain.) 18. I have not have been the beneficiary of a pardon, amnesty, rehabilitation decree, other act of clemency or similar action. (If you have been, explain.) 19. APPLICANTS FOR STATUS AS PERMANENT RESIDENTS MUST ESTABLISH THAT THEY ARE ADMISSIBLE TO THE UNITED STATES. EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE PROVIDED BY LAW, ALIENS WITHIN ANY OF THE FOLLOWING CLASSES ARE NOT ADMISSIBLE TO THE UNITED STATES AND ARE THEREFORE INELIGIBLE FOR STATUS AS PERMANENT RESIDENTS: Aliens who have committed or who have been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude (does not include minor traffic violations); aliens who have been engaged in or who intend to engage in any commercialized sexual activity; aliens who are or at any time have been, anarchists, or members of or affiliated with any Communist or other totalitarian party, including any subdivision or affiliate thereof; aliens who have advocated or taught, either by personal utterance, or by means of any written or printed matter, or through affiliation with an organization, (i) opposition to organized government, (ii) the overthrow of government by force or violence, (iii) the assaulting or killing of government officials because of their official character, (iv) the unlawful destruction of property, (v) sabotage, or (vi) the doctrines of world communism, or the establishment of a totalitarian dictatorship in the United States; aliens who intend to engage in prejudicial activities or unlawful activities of a subversive nature; aliens who have been convicted of violation of any law or regulation relating to narcotic drugs or marihuana, or who have been illicit traffickers in narcotic drugs or marihuana; aliens who have been involved in assisting any other aliens to enter the United States in violation of law; aliens who have applied for exemption or discharge from training or service in the Armed Forces of the United States on the ground of alienage and who have been relieved or discharged from such training or service; medical graduates (other than those for whom Relative petitions have been approved) coming principally to perform services as members of the medical profession, unless they have passed Parts I and II of the National Board of Medical Examiners Examination (or an equivalent examination as determined by the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services) and who are competent in oral and written English. Do any of the foregoing classes apply to you? No Yes (If answer is Yes, explain) 20. (COMPLETE THIS BLOCK ONLY IF YOU CHECKED BOX "A", "B", "C", or "D" OF BLOCK 1) APPLICANTS WHO CHECKED BOX "A" "B" "C" OR "D" OF BLOCK 1 IN ADDITION TO ESTABLISHING THAT THEY ARE NOT MEMBERS OF ANY OF THE INADMISSIBLE CLASSES DESCRIBED IN BLOCK 10 ABOVE MUST, EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE PROVIDED BY LAW, ALSO ESTABLISH THAT THEY ARE NOT WITHIN ANY OF THE FOLLOWING INADMISSIBLE CLASSES: Aliens who are mentally retarded, insane, or have suffered one or more attacks of insanity; aliens afflicted with psychopathic personality, sexual deviation, mental defect, narcotic drug addiction, chronic alcoholism or any dangerous contagious disease; aliens who have a physical defect, disease or disability affecting their ability to earn a living; aliens who are paupers, professional beggars or vagrants; aliens who are polygamists or advocate polygamy; aliens who intend to perform skilled or unskilled labor and who have not been certified by the Secretary of Labor (see Instruction 10); aliens likely to become a public charge; aliens who have been excluded from the United States within the past year, or who at any time have been deported from the United States, or who at any time have been removed from the United States at Government expenses; aliens who have procured or have attempted to procure a visa by fraud or misrepresentation; aliens who have departed from or remained outside the United States to avoid military service in time of war or national emergency; aliens who are former exchange visitors who are subject to but have not complied with the two year foreign residence requirement. Do any of the foregoing classes apply to you? No Yes (If answer is Yes, explain) 21. I do not do intend to seek gainful employment in the United States. If you intend to seek gainful employment in the United States, state the occupation you intend to follow.

full_text: CHAMA Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Cambridge Haman American Association me. 106 Windeor Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02139 Tel.(617)402-0622 A tax stamp No. 1701 E canceled tarif CERTIFICATE OF RELIGIOUS MARRIAGE Liberty Equality Fraternity Republic of Haiti Mcoflet In the year nineteen hundred seventy-three, Year 170 of Independance, and on Wednesday October tenth. We, Jacques M. Oriol, Civil Registrar of Port au Prince East sector, signature below. Having examined the documents transmitted to us by Father Lafontant, Pastor of the Sacred Heart Parish, in conformance with Article 6 of the Law of December 16 1929 as amended by that of January 26 1945. Do state, enregister, and certify that, the banns having been duly posted and no ob- jection having been indicated to the above-named minister of religion, Mister PIERRE GILBERT MAGNY, accountant, presenting his (#); twenty-nine years and seven months of age, born in Petionville, domiciled in Port au Prince; son of Breneville Magny, carpenter, domiciled in Port au Prince, and of Berenice Laurent, clerk, domi- ciled in Port au Prince; speaking for himself and on his own behalf on the one hand; and MARIE MONA PETIT, typist, duly presenting (#); twenty-seven years and seven months of age, born at Cap Haitian, domiciled in Port au Prince; daughter of Grandjean Petit, tailor, domiciled in Cap Haitian, and of Idora Pierre Paul, seamstress, domiciled in Cap haitian; speaking for herself and on her own behalf on the other hand; Presented themselves on August fourth nineteen hundred seventy-three at six-fifteen o'clock in the evening at the Church of the Sacred Heart in order to contract marriage. To the question if they consented to take each other for husband and wife, they re- plied each separately and in the affirmative in the presence of the above-named minis- ter a religion and of 1) Michel Gelin, professor, twenty-nine years of age, and of Mme Ghislaine Audouin, accountant, thirty-three years of age, both domiciled in Port au Prince. They have been thus joined in marriage. The certificate issued by the above minister of religion was signed by him: P. Lafontant. In witness whereof we have issued and signed this certificate, in conformance with the Law. (s) J. M. Oriol. two notes to the margin Signed: signature/stamp parish seal/ signature of priest: P. (617) 482-6622 A non-posts organization tax stamp MMM No. 45383 Liberty equality fraternity Republic of Haiti Excerpted from the minutes of the Clerk of the District Court of Port au Prince East section. Today, Monday the first day of the month of October nineteen hundred eighty- BC four, Year 181 of Independance, at ten o'clock in the morning. of Before Us, Raoul Saint-Cyr, Judge of the District Court of the capital East section, with the assistance of Louis Edner Duverneau, clerk. Day Appeared citizen Rose Garcon (also) known as Idora Pierre-Paul, landowner living and domiciled at Port au Prince, identification no. . Who declared to us that her certificate has been lost and that all attempts to find it in the places designated by law for its keeping have proved vain and fruit- less; and that she currently needs her birth certificate in order to prove her identity according to her rights. In conformance to Articles 70-71 of the Civil Code, she has brought before the bench three witnesses who will testify under oath that she was born on December 1st 1905 of the union of husband Cersius Pierre-Paul and the woman Jeancilia Pierre, both deceased. There have appeared: Philippe Emmanuel i.d. no. 9090-V Gerard Louis i.d. no. 4343-B Fedner Louis i.d. no. 4343-K All landowners living and domiciled at Port au Prince, Haitiens of legal age, enjoying their full civil and political rights. After a reading by the clerk of the preceding exposition, they have declared, certified, and sworn that they are perfectly well acquainted with the woman named Rose Garcon (also) known as Idora Pierre-Paul and that they know more importantly that she was born at Quartier Morin on December 1st 1905 of the legitimate union of husband Cercius Pierre-Paul and the woman maiden name Jeancilia Pierre, both deceased. Accordingly we have drawn up and concluded this report of the proceedings which we have signed with the principals and the clerk. Thus signed: Philippe Emmanuel, Gerard Louis, Fedner Louis, Raoul Saint-Cyr, Magistrate, and Louis Edner Duverneau, clerk Verified: Judge of the District Court of the capital, East section, for the authentification of the signature of the above named clerk (seal signature of Judge) Certified Copy Collated Clerk Louis Edner Duverneau (seal signature of clerk) Left margin Certificate of Identity of Rose Carcon (also) known as Idora Pierre-Paul Born at Quartier Morin on December 1st 1905 of the legitimate union of husband Cersius Pierre-Paul and the woman, maiden name, Jeancilia Pierre, both deceased Bonny J. ,Saintelot, Notary Public My commission expires May 28 1987

Dorchester, MA 02124 201 (b) A26 875 947 DATE PETITION FILED DATE OF APPROVAL OF PETITION 1/31/85 4/1/85 Date: 4/3/85 Please be advised that approval of the petition confers upon the beneficiary an appropriate classification. The approval constitutes no assurance that the beneficiary will be found eligible for visa issuance, admission to the United States or adjustment to lawful permanent resident status. Eligibility for visa issuance is determined only when application therefor is made to a consular officer; eligibility for admission or adjustment is determined only when application therefor is made to an immigration officer. Also, please note the items below which are indicated by "X" marks concerning this petition: YOUR PETITION TO CLASSIFY THE BENEFICIARY AS AN IMMEDIATE RELATIVE OF A UNITED STATES CITIZEN HAS BEEN FORWARDED TO THE UNITED 1. STATES CONSULATEAT Port-au-Prince, Haita HIS COMPLETES ALL ACTION BY THIS SERVICE ON THE PETITION. THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE, WHICH IS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WILL ADVISE THE BENEFICIARY CONCERNING VISA ISSUANCE Inquiry concerning visa issuance should be addressed to the Consul. This Service will be unable to answer any inquiry concerning visa issuance. 2. IF YOU BECOME NATURALIZED AS A CITIZEN OF THE UNITED STATES AND AN IMMIGRANT VISA HAS NOT YET BEEN ISSUED TO THE BENEFICIARY, NOTIFY THIS OFFICE IMMEDIATELY, GIVING THE DATE OF YOUR NATURALIZATION AT THE SAME TIME, IF THE PETITION WAS IN BEHALF OF YOUR SON OR DAUGHTER, ALSO ADVISE WHETHER THAT PERSON IS STILL UNMARRIED. THIS INFORMATION MAY EXPEDITE THE ISSUANCE OF A VISA TO THE BENEFICIARY YOUR PETITION FOR PREFERENCE CLASSIFICATION, AS SHOWN ABOVE, HAS BEEN FORWARDED TO THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE AT 3. THIS COMPLETES ALL ACTION BY THIS SERVICE ON THE PETITION. THIS SERVICE HAS . NOTHING TO DO WITH THE ACTUAL ISSUANCE OF VISAS. VISAS ARE ISSUED ONLY BY UNITED STATES CONSULS WHO ARE UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE UNDER THE LAW ONLY A LIMITED NUMBER OF VISAS MAY BE ISSUED BY THAT DEPART- MENT DURING EACH YEAR AND THEY MUST BE ISSUED STRICTLY IN THE CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER IN WHICH PETITIONS WERE FILED FOR THE SAME CLASSIFICATION. WHEN THE BENEFICIARY'S TURN IS REACHED ON THE VISA WAITING LIST. THE UNITED STATES CONSUL WILL INFORM HIM AND CONSIDER ISSUANCE OF THE VISA. Inquiry concerning visa issuance should be addressed to the Consul. This Service will be unable to answer any inquiry concerning visa issuance. 4. THE PETITION STATES THAT THE BENEFICIARY IS IN THE UNITED STATES AND WILL APPLY TO BECOME A LAWFUL PERMANENT RESIDENT THE ENCLOSED APPLICATION FOR THIS PURPOSE (FORM 1-485) SHOULD BE COMPLETED AND SUBMITTED BY THE BENEFICIARY WITHIN 30 DAYS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE INSTRUCTIONS CONTAINED THEREIN. (IF THE BENEFICIARY HAD PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTED FORM I-485 WHICH WAS RETURNED TO HIM, HE SHOULD RESUBMIT THAT FORM WITHIN 30 DAYS.) 5. THE BENEFICIARY WILL BE INFORMED OF THE DECISION MADE ON HIS PENDING APPLICATION TO BECOME A LAWFUL PERMANENT RESIDENT (FORM I-485). 6. THE PETITION STATES THAT THE BENEFICIARY IS IN THE UNITED STATES AND WILL APPLY TO BECOME A LAWFUL PERMANENT RESIDENT. HOWEVER, AN IMMIGRANT VISA NUMBER IS NOT PRESENTLY AVAILABLE THEREFORE THE BENEFICIARY MAY NOT APPLY TO BECOME A PER- MANENT RESIDENT. 7. ORIGINAL DOCUMENTS SUBMITTED IN SUPPORT OF YOUR PETITION UNACCOMPANIED BY COPIES THEREOF HAVE BEEN MADE A PERMANENT PART OF THE PETITION. ANY OTHERS ARE RETURNED HEREWITH. 8. REMARKS VERY TRULY YOURS, Chorlas DISTRICT DIRECTOR Form 1-171 (Rev. 4-2-81) Y

full_text: U.S. Department of Justice Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Immigration and Naturalization Service Notice of Action ANGE NOTICE DATE Request That Applicant Appear For Naturalization Initial Interview May 08, 2001 CASE TYPE INS All N400 Application For Naturalization A 026 875 947 APPLICATION NUMBER RECEIVED DATE PRIORITY DATE PAGE SSC*000045141 September 10, 1998 September 10, 1998 of 1 APPLICANT NAME AND MAILING ADDRESS Please come to: ROSE G PETIT MIAMI CUSA OFFICE 40 NW 186 TERR 77 SE FIFTH ST MIAMI FL 33169 2ND FLOOR NATURALIZATION INTERVIEW MIAMI FL 33131 On (Date): Thursday, June 07,2001 At (Time): 07:50 AM You are hereby notified to appear for an interview on your Application for Naturalization at the date, time, and place indicated above. Waiting room capacity is limited. Please do not arrive any earlier than 30 minutes before your scheduled appointment time. The proceeding will take about two hours. If for any reason you cannot keep this appointment, return this letter immediately with your explanation and a request for a new appointment; otherwise, no further action will be taken on your application. If you are applying for citizenship for yourself, you will be tested on your knowledge of the government and history of the United States. You will also be tested on reading, writing, and speaking English, unless on the day you filed your application, you have been living in the United States for a total of at least 20 years as a lawful permanent resident and are over 50 years old, or you have been living in the United States for a total of 15 years as a lawful permanent resident and are over 55 years old, or unless you have a medically determinable disability (you must have filed form N648 Medical Certification for Disability Exception, with your N400 Application for Naturalization). You MUST BRING the following with you to the interview: This letter. Your Alien Registration Card (green card). Any evidence of Selective Service Registration. Your passport and/or any other documents you used in connection with any entries into the United States. Those items noted below which are applicable to you: If applying for NATURALIZATION AS THE SPOUSE of a United States Citizen; Your marriage certificate. Proof of death or divorce for each prior marriage of yourself or spouse. Your spouse's birth or naturalization certificate or certificate of citizenship. If applying for NATURALIZATION as a member of the United States Armed Forces; Your discharge certificate, or form DD 214. If copies of a document were submitted as evidence with your N400 application, the originals of those documents should be brought to the interview. PLEASE keep this appointment, even if you do not have all the items indicated above. If you have any questions or comments regarding this notice or the status of your case, please contact our office at the below address or customer service number. You will be notified separately about any other cases you may have filed. INS Office Address: INS Customer Service Number: US IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE (214)381-1423 P.O. form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: General Information Notice for Petition Approval,, I-458, Application to Register Permanent Residence or Adjust Status.

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 Please save this notice for your records. Please enclose a copy if you have to write us or a U.S. Consulate about this case, or if you file another application based on this decision. You will be notified separately about any other applications or petitions you have filed. Additional Information GENERAL. APPROVAL OF AN IMMIGRANT PETITION. The filing of an application or petition does not in itself allow Approval of an immigrant petition does not convey any right a person to enter the United States and does not confer any or status. The approved petition simply establishes a basis other right or benefit. upon which the person you filed for can apply for an immigrant or fiance(e) visa or for adjustment of status. INQUIRIES. A person is not guaranteed issuance of a visa or a grant of adjustment simply because this petition is approved. Those pro- You should contact the office listed on the reverse of this cesses look at additional criteria. notice if you have questions about the notice, or questions about the status of your application or petition. form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: ATTACHMENT TO FORM N-14

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/11/2023 ATTACHMENT TO FORM N-14 NAME: Rose PETIT FILE NO: 875947 You must bring the following information or document (s) checked to your next interview (see Form N-14). Failure to do so may result in denial of your application. Government Test Writing Test Reading Test Complete Preliminary Examination Proof of your continuous residence & your physical presence in the U.S. from to Present including (1) passports, (2) proof of income or means of support, (3) rent/mortgage statements & utility bills, (4) bank, credit card & loan statements showing regular transactions, (5) car registration & insurance & (6) school records. Bring all original documents and a photocopy of each document. A list of trips made outside the U.S. from to Present with the date of departure, the date of return, the destination & the reason for each trip and all passports. A list of all your addresses from to Present. A list of all your employers with addresses, from to Present. If you were unemployed, included the dates of your unemployment. Original Marriage Certificate, Original evidence of your spouse's citizenship, proof that the marriage is in good standing. Bring all original documents and a photocopy of each document. Transcript of your Driver's Record for the last 7 years. Applications are obtainable from the Department of Motor Vehicles. CERTIFIED copies of the ARREST REPORT AND/OR ALL CHARGES, FINAL DISPOSITION, and SENTENCE for: A police clearance from all the jurisdictions, where you have been residing from to Present. A letter from your religious denomination that you are a member in good standing. A statement from your religious denomination regarding its principle regarding the bearing of arms and a statement expressing your own personal beliefs about the same. Evidence of registration with the Selective Service before the age of 26. IF YOU DID NOT REGISTER BEFORE THE AGE OF 26, SUBMIT BOTH: a letter of explanation as to the reason you failed to register & a letter from Selective Service as to whether they had written to you notifying you to register. For proof of registration or a letter from Selective Service, call (888) 655-1825 or (847) 688-6888. If you are under 26 and need to register, applications are available at the Post Office. Proof of child support from to Present. Please include your Divorce Decree and/or Court Order concerning the matter of child support. Bring all original documents and a photocopy of each document. Two Color Photos. The photos must be glossy, unretouched and unmounted, and have a white background. Dimension of the face should be about 1 inch from chin to top of hair. Face should be 3/4 frontal view of right side with right ear visible. YOU MUST BRING ALL ORIGINAL DOCUMENTS AND A PHOTOCOPY OF EACH DOCUMENT TO YOUR INTERVIEW. DAO Name: RILL sing SDAO Initials REV. 9/16/98

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Oath of Allegiance, N-4-1203

full_text: Oath of Allegiance I hereby declare, on oath, (affirm) that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state, or sovereignty of whom or which I have heretofore been a sub- ject or citizen; that I will support and defend the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform noncombatant service in the Armed Forces of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by the law; and that I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion: So HELP ME GOD. In acknowledgment whereof I have hereunto affixed my signature. Margant Pracentine Subscribed and sworn (affirmed) to before me, a designated representative of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, this 16 day of may 1941 , 0 Days (Title) n.E. , 19 I hereby certify that I have this day received original certificate of citizenship of which this is a duplicate.

Dear Sir: One JOHN COLISTRO , native of ITALY, born 2-11-69 is alleged to have been naturalized in your court on OK about on Jan. 10, 1900. Please search your records, and, if one is found covering the alleged naturalization, insert the data called for on the reverse of this letter, or so much thereof as may be shown by the record; sign the form in the space provided for your signature; affix your official seal there- to; and return the form to this office. A self-addressed envelope is enclosed for your conven- ience. " A reply by return mail will be appreciated. If your records do not disclose the naturalization of the person referred to above, please enter on the form the legend "No Record" over your signature. In that event, if your records disclose that the person referred to filed a declaration of intention, please fill in the lower por- tion of this letter and return this letter with a tracing of the declarant's signature. The excludeable classes are described below in general terms. You should read carefully the following list and answer YES or NO to each category. EXCEPT AS OTHERWISE PROVIDED BY LAW, ALIENS WITHIN THE FOLLOWING CLASSIFICATIONS ARE INELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE A VISA. DO ANY OF THE FOLLOWING CLASSES APPLY TO YOU? a. An alien who has a communicable disease of public health significance, or has or has had a physical or mental disorder that poses, or is likely to pose a threat to the safety or welfare of the alien or others; an alien who is a drug abuser or .(212(a)(1)} Yes No b. An alien convicted of, or who admits committing a crime involving moral turpitude, or violation of any law relating to a controlled substance; an alien convicted of 2 or more offenses for which the aggregate sentences were 5 years or more; an alien coming to the United States to engage in prostitution or commercialized vice, or who has engaged in prostitution or procuring within the past 10 years; an alien who is or has been an illicit trafficker in any controlled substance; an alien who has committed a serious criminal offense in the United States and who has asserted immunity from prosecution. (212 (a)(2) Yes No C. Alien who seeks to enter the United States to engage in espionage, sabotage, export control violations, overthrow of the Government of the United States, or other unlawful activity, an alien who seeks to enter the United States to engage in terrrorist activities; an alien who has been a member of or affiliated with the Communist or any other totalitarian party; an alien who under the direction of the Nazi government of Germany, or any area occupied by, or allied with the Nazi Government of Germany, ordered, incited, assisted, or otherwise participated in the persecution of any person because of race, religion, national origin, or political opinion; an alien who has engaged in genocide (212(a)(3)) Yes No d. An alien who is likely to become a public charge (212(a)(4) Yes No e. An alien who seeks to enter for the purpose of performing skilled or unskilled labor who has not been certified by the Secretary of Labour an alien graduate of a foreign medical school seeking to perform medical services who has not passed the NBME exam or its Yes No equivalent.(212(a)(5) Not Applicable f. form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Declaration by Immigrant’s Sponsor Under the Social Security Act, BMB-28

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/15/2023 CONSULATE GENERAL OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA 78, Bhulabhai Desai Road, Bombay 400 0 026, India DECLARATION BY IMMIGRANT'S SPONSOR UNDER THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACT IMPORTANT: This document must be read and signed by persons wishing to submit an affidavit of support on behalf of an alien applying for an immigrant visa. A signed copy of this document must be attached to each copy of any affidavit oi support submitted on behalf of an applicant. The Social Security Act, as amended, establishes certain requir ements for determining the eligibility of aliens for Supplemental Security Income (SSI) and Aid to Families with Depen- dent Children (AFDC) benefits. The Food Stamp Act, as amended contains similar provisions. These amendments require that the income and resources of a y person (and that person's spouse) who executes an affidavit of support or similar agreem nt on behalf of an immigrant alien, be deemed to be the income and resources of the alien nder formulas for determining eligibility for SSI, AFDC, and Food Stamp benefits during the three years following the alien's entry into the United States. The eligibility of aliens for SSI, AFDC, and Food Stamp benefits will be contingent upon their obtaining the cooperation of their sponsors in providing the necessary information and evi- dence to enable the Social Security Administration and/or State Welfare Agencies to carry out these provisions. An alien applying for SSI, AFDC, or Food Stamp benefits must make available to the Social Security Administration and/or State Welfare Agencies documentation concerning his income or resources or those of his sponsors, including information which he provided in support of his application for an immigrant visa or adjustment of status. The Secretary of Health and Human Services and/or State Welfare Agencies are authorized to obtain copies of any such documentation from other agencies. The Social Security Act and the Food Stamp Act also provide that an alien and his or her sponsor shall be jointly and severally liable to repay any SSI, AFDC, and Food Stamp benefits which are incorrectly paid because of misinformation provided by sponsor or because of sponsor's failure to provide information. Also, any incorrect payments of SSI and AFDC benefits which are not repaid will be withheld from any subsequent payments for which the alien or sponsors are otherwise eligible under the Social Security Act. These provisions do not apply to aliens admitted as refugees or granted political asylum by the Attorney General. They also will not apply to the SSI eligibility of aliens who become blind or disabled after entry into the United States. The AFDC provisions do not apply to aliens who are dependent children of the sponsor or sponsor's spouse. form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Pelvic Pain

full_text: Screened by NARA, 7/13/2023 Page: 1 For DURUPADI WADHWANT, Friday, October 27, 2000, 7:20 pm To reach use Emergency Department 973-971-5004 Work Med- 973-971-7700 PELVIC PAIN: Your exam shows your pain is probably from OUT pelvic organs (ovaries, tubes, uterus). Common causes of pelvig pain include: ovulation, cysts of the ovaries, infection, endometriosis, and tumors. More serious causes of pain in the pelvis that require surgery are appendicitis and ectopic (tubal) pregnancy. Often the exact cause cannot be found with a single exam. Blood tests, cultures, and a follow-up check with a gynecologist may be needed. You should rest in bed with your legs propped up until your pain is much better Avoid sex until your symptoms are improved and your doctor says it is safe. If your stomach is upset. stick to small amounts of clear liquids until you feel better. Pain medicine is sometimes needed. Contact your doctor for a follow-up exam as recommended Please call right away or go to the emergency room if you have any of these symptoms * Uprov of Fainting, severe weakness, repeated vomiting, dehydration. * Heavy vaginal bleeding or passing solid tissue. Fever or chills. I acknowledge receipt of this written instruction sheet, which I will read and review. I will arrange for follow up care indicated above. Patient or Legal Guardian signature Please return to the Emergency Department immediately if your condition worsens. Join with primary doctor pubic ramus fracture (stable)

form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: INSTRUCTIONS, I-123

full_text: Screened by NARA, 7/13/2023 LOKW 1-181 (BEAT 21016 unwpet LOL allocation INSTRUCTIONS LOLLU e-123 GENERAL: To request allocation of a visa number for a preference or nonpreference case under Section 245 or for a Western Hemisphere number under Section 1 of the Act of November 2, 1966, mail original and one copy to Visa Control Office. When grant of permanent residence becomes final, the copy returned by the Visa Control Office which allocates the visa number shall be appropriately endorsed, and placed in the filé. In such cases the triplicate copy, which was retained in the file, shall be noted to show the date permanent residence status is granted and forwarded to the State Director of Selective Service in the case of every male alien born on or after September 15, 1925, and who has reached 18 years of age. If not required for this purpose, it shall be destroyed. In cases where permanent residence is granted without referral to the Visa Control Office, except where Selective Service is to be notified, only an original 1-181 need be prepared and placed in the file. In other cases where outstanding instructions require the form -181 to be forwarded to the Visa Control Office, it shall be prepared in dup- licate and the original placed in the file, except when an additional copy is required to notify Selective Service. DISTIBICI PREFERENCE: Under Section 245, the priority date will be the filing date of one of the first six preference petitions. ACTION NONPREFERENCE: Under Section 245, the priority date shall be fixed by the following factors, whichever is the earliest; (1) the priority date accorded the applicant by the consular officer as a nonpreference immigrant; (2) the date on which application Form 1-485 is properly filed, if the applicant establishes that he is a member of a profession or a person with exceptional ability in the sciences or the arts not included in the Department of Labor's Schedule A (29 CFR 60) provided a certification is issued on that basis, or that he is within Schedule A, or that the provisions of Section 212(a)(14) of the Act do not apply to him; (3) the date on which an ap- proved valid third or sixth preference visa petition in his behalf was filed; or (4) the date an application for certification based on a job offer was accepted for processing by any office within the employment service system of the Department of Labor, provided the certification applied for was issued. A nonpreference priority date, once established, is retained by the alien even though at the time a visa number becomes available and he is allotted a nonpreference visa number he meets the provisions of Section 212 (a) (14) of the Act by some means other than that by which he originally established entitlement to the nonpreference priority date. LABOR CERTIFICATION: Check and complete the block regarding certifications on the form as appropriate in a nonpreference case. S-S REMARKS: If the visa number requested is based on Section 202(b)(1), (2), (3) or (4) or Section 203(a)(9) of the Act explain as appropriate in "Remarks" block INCTS DELAY NOTICE: When the Service a visa number from the Department of State before granting permane interesident the letter portion of this form notifying of the delay is mailed to the applicant with copy to the attorney of record. full_text: Screened by NARA, 7/13/2023 UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE A19 529 822 (245) FILE NO.: be 20 WEST BROADWAY NEW YORK, N. Y. 10007 DATE: October 19, 1972 MEDICAL EXAMINATION AND IMMIGRATION INTERVIEW Durupadi J. Wadhwni 97-11 Horace Harding Expwy. Apt. 18-K Lefrak, City, New York 11368 INSTRUCTIONS FOR MEDICAL EXAMINATION A MEDICAL EXAMINATION IS NECESSARY AS PART OF YOUR APPLICATION FOR ADJUSTMENT OF STATUS TO THAT OF A PER. MANENT RESIDENT. WHEN YOU APPEAR FOR THE MEDICAL EXAMINATION BRING WITH YOU THIS LETTER, THE TWO ATTACHED COPIES, AND THE FOLLOWING: 1. X-RAY FILM (14" x 17") OF YOUR CHEST, UNLESS YOU ARE UNDER 11 YEARS OF AGE, AND A REPORT BY A LICENSED PHYSICIAN INTERPRETING IT. FILM MUST NOT BE MORE THAN 30 DAYS OLD. 2. SEROLOGY REPORT, UNLESS YOU ARE UNDER 15 YEARS OF AGE. SEROLOGIC TEST FOR SYPHILIS MUST NOT BE MORE THAN 30 DAYS OLD. THIS X-RAY AND TEST MUST BE ACCOMPLISHED BY A LICENSED PHYSICIAN OR A STATE OR LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT APPROVED LABORATORY. IF YOU DO NOT HAVE A PERSONAL PHYSICIAN, YOU MAY WISH TO TELEPHONE YOUR STATE OR LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT FOR THE NAME OF AN APPROVED LABORATORY THAT MAY BE ABLE TO PERFORM THE X-RAY AND TEST REQUIRED. PLEASE NOTE THE BOX CHECKED BELOW WITH REGARD TO YOUR MEDICAL EXAMINATION. AN APPOINTMENT HAS BEEN MADE FOR YOU TO BE EXAMINED BY A PHYSICIAN OF THE U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE AT: USPHS Outpatient Clinic ADDRESS: November 1, 1972 245 West Houston Street DATE: Between New York, New York 10014 TIME: 8:00 AND 10:00 AM PLEASE ARRANGE FOR YOUR MEDICAL EXAMINATION WITH THE BELOW LISTED PHYSICIAN AT THE ADDRESS SHOWN. THE EXAMINATION SHOULD BE COMPLETED BEFORE PHYSICIAN'S NAME AND ADDRESS: PLEASE SHOW THE COPIES OF THIS LETTER TO YOUR PHYSICIAN (OR LABORATORY) PERFORMING THE EXAMINATION AND FURNISH HIM WITH YOUR SIGNATURE, WRITTEN IN HIS PRESENCE FOR INCLUSION WITH HIS REPORT. TO PHYSICIAN PERFORMING THE EXAMINATION PLEASE OBTAIN THE APPLICANT'S SIGNATURE IN THE SPACE PROVIDED AND MEDICALLY EXAMINE HIM FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR ADJUSTMENT OF STATUS. IF THE APPLICANT IS FREE OF MEDICAL DEFECTS LISTED IN SECTION 212 (A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT, ENDORSE THIS COPY OF FORM 1-486A IN THE SPACE PROVIDED AND HAND IT TO THE APPLICANT IN A SEALED ENVELOPE FOR PRESENTATION AT HIS IMMIGRATION INTERVIEW. IF THE APPLICANT IS NOT FREE OF SUCH MEDICAL DEFECTS. DO NOT SIGN THIS FORM; INSTEAD WRITE "SEE FS-398" IN THE PHYSICIAN'S SIGNATURE BLOCK AND PREPARE MEDICAL CERTIFICATE ON FORM FS-398 AND HAND IT TO THE APPLICANT IN A SEALED ENVELOPE TOGETHER WITH THIS COPY OF FORM 1-486A FOR PRESENTATION AT HIS IMMIGRATION INTERVIEW. (IF EXAMINATION IS CONDUCTED BY A CIVIL SURGEON, INSERT IN ENVELOPE BOTH COPIES OF FORM 1-486A; X-RAYS AND LABORATORY REPORTS; AND TWO COPIES OF FORM FS-398 IF APPLICANT IS NOT FREE OF MEDICAL DEFECTS.) DISTRICT DIRECTOR I CERTIFY THAT THE ATTACHED X-RAY AND SEROLOGY REPORT, (BLOOD TEST) RELATE TO ME. SIGNATURE OF APPLICANT: pnyupad PENALTY: THE LAW PROVIDES SEVERE PENALTIES FOR KNOWINGLY ANDWILFULLY FALSIFYING OR CONCEALING X A MATERIAL FACT OR USING ANY FALSE DOCUMENTS IN CONNECTION WITH THIS APPLICATION. MY EXAMINATI ON INCLUDING X-RAY, BLOOD SEROLOGICAL AND OTHER REPORTS, WHEN NEEDED, SHOW THE APPLICANT TO BE FREE OF ANY DEFECTS, DISEASES OF DISABILITIES LISTED IN SECTION 212(A) OF THE IMMIGRATION AND NATIONALITY ACT AS AMENDED SIGNATURE OF PHYSICIAN TITLE m newton DATE 11-1-72 FORM I-486 A (REV. 9-1-71) Y

YOUR PETITION TO CLASSIFY THE BENEFICIARY AS AN IMMEDIATE RELATIVE OF A UNITED STATES CITIZEN HAS BEEN APPROVED AND FORWARDED TO THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE AT. WILL ADVISE THE BENEFICIARY CON- CERNING VISA ISSUANCE Inquiry concerning visa issuance should be addressed to the Consul. This Service will be unable to answer any inquiry concerning visa issuance. 2. IF YOU BECOME NATURALIZED AS A CITIZEN OF THE UNITED STATES AND AN IMMIGRANT VISA HAS NOT YET BEEN ISSUED TO THE BENEFICIARY NOTIFY THIS OFFICE IMMEDIATELY, GIVING THE DATE OF YOUR NATURALIZATION. AT THE SAME TIME. IF THE PETITION WAS IN BEHALF OF YOUR SON OR DAUGHTER, ALSO ADVISE WHETHER THAT PERSON IS STILL UNMARRIED. THIS INFORMATION MAY EXPEDITE THE ISSUANCE OF A VISA TO THE BENEFICIARY. 3. YOUR PETITION FOR PREFERENCE CLASSIFICATION. AS SHOWN ABOVE. HAS BEEN APPROVED BY THE SERVICE AND FORWARDED TO THE UNITED THIS SERVICE HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH THE ACTUAL ISSUANCE OF VISAS. VISAS ARE ISSUED ONLY BY UNITED STATES CONSULS WHO ARE UNDER STATES CONSULATE AT THIS COMPLETES ALL ACTION BY THIS SERVICE ON THE PETITION THE JURISDICTION OF THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE. UNDER THE LAW ONLY A LIMITED NUMBER OF VISAS MAY BE ISSUED BY THAT DEPARTMENT DURING EACH YEAR AND THEY MUST BE ISSUED STRICTLY IN THE CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER IN WHICH PETITIONS WERE FILED FOR THE SAME CLAS- SIFICATION. WHEN THE BENEFICIARY'S TURN IS REACHED ON THE VISA WAITING LIST. THE UNITED STATES CONSUL WILL INFORM HIM AND CON- SIDER ISSUANCE OF THE VISA. Inquiry concerning visa issuance should be addressed to the Consul. This Service will be unable to answer any inquiry con- cerning visa issuance. 41 X THE PETITION HAS BEEN APPROVED THE PETITION STATES THAT THE BENEFICIARY IS IN THE UNITED STATES AND WILL APPLY TO BECOME A LAW- FUL PERMANENT RESIDENT. THE ENCLOSED APPLICATION FOR THIS PURPOSE (FORM 1-485) SHOULD BE COMPLETED AND SUBMITTED BY THE BENEFICIARY IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE INSTRUCTIONS CONTAINED THEREIN. (IF THE BENEFICIARY HAD PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTED FORM 1.485 WHICH WAS RETURNED TO HIM, HE SHOULD RESUBMIT THAT FORM.) 5. THE PETITION HAS BEEN APPROVED. THE BENEFICIARY WILL BE INFORMED OF THE DECISION MADE ON HIS PENDING APPLICATION TO BECOME A LAWFUL PERMANENT RESIDENT (FORM 1-485). 6. THE PETITION HAS BEEN APPROVED. THE PETITION STATES THAT THE BENEFICIARY IS IN THE UNITED STATES AND WILL APPLY TO BECOME A LAW- FUL PERMANENT RESIDENT HOWEVER, AN IMMIGRANT VISA NUMBER IS NOT PRESENTLY AVAILABLE. THEREFORE. THE BENEFICIARY MAY NOT APPLY TO BECOME A PERMANENT RESIDENT. 7. THE PETITION HAS BEEN APPROVED HOWEVER, SINCE THE BENEFICIARY IS A NATIVE OF THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE. HE IS INELIGIBLE TO BE- COME A LAWFUL PERMANENT RESIDENT OTHER THAN BY DEPARTING FROM THE UNITED STATES AND REENTERING IN POSSESSION OF AN IMMI- GRANT VISA ISSUED BY AN AMERICAN CONSUL 8. Your petition to confer preference under section 203(a)(6) of the Immigration and Nationality Act cannot be accepted unless accompanied by a certification from the Secretary of Labor or his designated representative. To apply for the certification, attached Forms MA 7-50 (A and B), and the evidence of the alien's qualifications must be filed in the local state employment service office. The Forms MA 7-50A and B and the evidence will be returned to you, with the certification stamped on the form if a certification is issued. You may then file the petition at this office, at- taching all papers and documents returned to you by the Department of Labor. 12. Request your (prospective) employer to complete Form MA 7-50B, and to submit the Forms MA 7-50A and B and evidence of your qualifications to the local state employment service office. If the Labor Department issues a certification, your employer should return to you the evidence of your qualifications and Forms MA 7-50A and B with the certification stamped on Form MA 7-50, for submission with your application. (Forms MA 7-50 A and B with instructions are attached.) 13. You have indicated that you do not intend to seek employment. You must furnish evidence that you have sufficient funds or other means of maintaining yourself in this country. 14. Furnish two photographs, 1 1/2" x 1 1/2" with distance from top of head to point of chin 1 1/4" Machine-made photos not acceptable. 5. Resubmit your application with an approved visa petition in your behalf. Also complete form G-325A where checked in red(Five years employment is required) and return. Wadhwni 97-11 Horace Harding Expuy. Apt. 18-K Lefrak, City, New York 11368 INSTRUCTIONS FOR MEDICAL EXAMINATION A MEDICAL EXAMINATION IS NECESSARY AS PART OF YOUR APPLICATION FOR ADJUSTMENT OF STATUS TO THAT OF A PER. MANENT RESIDENT. WHEN YOU APPEAR FOR THE MEDICAL EXAMINATION BRING WITH YOU THIS LETTER, THE TWO ATTACHED COPIES, AND THE FOLLOWING: 1. X-RAY FILM (14" x 17") OF YOUR CHEST, UNLESS YOU ARE UNDER 11 YEARS OF AGE, AND A REPORT BY A LICENSED PHYSICIAN INTERPRETING IT. FILM MUST NOT BE MORE THAN 30 DAYS OLD. 2. SEROLOGY REPORT, UNLESS YOU ARE UNDER 15 YEARS OF AGE. SEROLOGIC TEST FOR SYPHILIS MUST NOT BE MORE THAN 30 DAYS OLD. THIS X-RAY AND TEST MUST BE ACCOMPLISHED BY A LICENSED PHYSICIAN OR A STATE OR LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT APPROVED LABORATORY. IF YOU DO NOT HAVE A PERSONAL PHYSICIAN, YOU MAY WISH TO TELEPHONE YOUR STATE OR LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENT FOR THE NAME OF AN APPROVED LABORATORY THAT MAY BE ABLE TO PERFORM THE X-RAY AND TEST REQUIRED. PLEASE NOTE THE BOX CHECKED BELOW WITH REGARD TO YOUR MEDICAL EXAMINATION. AN APPOINTMENT HAS BEEN MADE FOR YOU TO BE EXAMINED BY A PHYSICIAN OF THE U.S. PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE AT: November 1, 1972 ADDRESS: DATE: Between 8:00 AND 10:00 AM TIME: PLEASE ARRANGE FOR YOUR MEDICAL EXAMINATION WITH THE BELOW LISTED PHYSICIAN AT THE ADDRESS SHOWN. THE EXAMINATION SHOULD BE COMPLETED BEFORE PHYSICIAN'S NAME AND ADDRESS: PLEASE SHOW THE COPIES OF THIS LETTER TO YOUR PHYSICIAN (OR LABORATORY) PERFORMING THE EXAMINATION AND FURNISH HIM WITH YOUR SIGNATURE, WRITTEN IN HIS PRESENCE FOR INCLUSION WITH HIS REPORT. INSTRUCTIONS FOR IMMIGRATION INTERVIEW AN APPOINTMENT HAS ALSO BEEN MADE FOR AN INTERVIEW BEFORE AN IMMIGRATION OFFICERAT ADDRESS: DATE: November 2, 1972 10:45 AM ErS TIME: BRING WITH YOU AT THE TIME OF INTERVIEW THE ITEMS CHECKED BELOW: THE SEALED ENVELOPE FURNISHED TO YOU BY THE PHYSICIAN WHO PERFORMED THE MEDICAL EXAMINATION. YOUR PASSPORT AND FORM 1-94 Asfidavit of support. IF YOU DO NOT SPEAK ENGLISH, A PERSON OF YOUR OWN SEX WHO CAN ACT AS INTERPRETER E: SHOULD ACCOMPANY YOU TO THE MEDICAL EXAMINATION AND IMMIGRATION INTERVIEW. FAILURE TO KEEP THESE APPOINTMENTS AND TO BRING THE REPORTS AND DOCUMENTS REQUIRED WILL DELAY YOUR CASE. DISTRICT DIRECTOR FILE COPY

If petition is for a person in the professions, arts or sciences, or an employee, the approval Please the ems below which are indicated by "X" marks concerning the visa petition filed by you in behalf of the above beneficiary 1. YOUR PETITION TO CLASSIFY THE BENEFICIARY AS AN IMMEDIATE RELATIVE OF A UNITED STATES CITIZEN HAS BEEN APPROVED AND FORWARDED TO THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE AT THIS COMPLETES ALL ACTION BY THIS SERVICE ON THE PETI- TION. THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE, WHICH IS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE. WILL ADVISE THE BENEFICIARY CON- CERNING VISA ISSUANCE Inquiry concerning visa issuance should be addressed to the Consul. This Service will be unable to answer any inquiry concerning visa issuance 2. IF YOU BECOME NATURALIZED AS A CITIZEN OF THE UNITED STATES AND AN IMMIGRANT VISA HAS NOT YET BEEN ISSUED TO THE BENEFICIARY NOTIFY THIS OFFICE IMMEDIATELY GIVING THE DATE OF YOUR NATURALIZATION AT THE SAME TIME. IF THE PETITION WAS IN BEHALF OF YOUR SON OR TAUCHTER ALSO ADVISE WHETHER THAT PERSON is STILL UNMARRIED THIS INFORMATION MAY EXPEDITE THE ISSUANCE OF A VISA TO THE BEACHILLARY 3. YOUR PETERS FOR PREFERENCE CLASSIFICATION AS SHOWN ABOVE. HAS BEEN APPROVED BY THE SERVICE AND FORWARDED TO THE UNITED STATES CONSULATE AT THIS COMPLETES ALL ACTION BY THIS SERVICE ON THE PETITION THIS s RVIC HAS NORHING TO DO WITH THE ACTUAL ISSUANCE OF VISAS VISAS ARE ISSUED ONLY BY UNITED STATES CONSULS WHO ARE UNDER THE SOUTON OF THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE UNDER THE LAW ONLY A LIMITED NUMBER OF VISAS MAY BE ISSUED BY THAT DEPARTMENT DURIN EAC YEAR AND THEY MUST BE ISSUED STRICTLY IN THE CHRONOLOGICAL ORDER IN WHICH PETITIONS WERE FILED FOR THE SAME CLAS- SIFIC.
